She regrets very much that she was not able to get an education, but her parents did not have economic resources and she had to start working when she was very young.  She also migrated to cities other than her own in search of a better standard of living. She worked very hard for a long time as a domestic, but at age 47 she decided to start her own tortilla business. With an old tin pan, 2 bundles of firewood and a pound of corn, she started her humble business.  Now she has been working in her tortilla business for 8 years; she makes the tortillas and sells them in her neighborhood. Most of her customers are housewives who, from the early hours, await the opening of her business so that they can have her warm and recently made corn tortillas for breakfast.

Guadalupe is taking this loan to buy corn, firewood, lime and beans.  These are the raw materials that she uses to make and sell her delicious tortillas.  One of her plans is to gradually make improvements to her house and to the kitchen where she makes the tortillas and cooked beans that she sells.

loans.use: to buy corn, firewood, lime and beans

loans.name: Yem

texts.en:
Yem, 59, is a resident of Pouk district, Siem Reap province, where she grows rice and beans for her livelihood. Yem has been involved in farming for more than 12 years. She is a very an industrious mother who has managed her entire farming business since her husband passed away. She has 4 children; 3 of them have independent lives and are already married. So there is only one child who is supported by her income. Yem plans to support her last-born child until he finishes high school. 

Yem is taking out this loan to buy a pump that can used to provide water to her bean crops. She won’t worry about how to carry water from the river to water her crops any longer. Yem hopes that someday she will be able to buy a few pieces of land to increase her productivity in her farming business.

loans.use: to buy a pump.

loans.name: Magno

texts.es: Carlos, de 33 años de edad, es un hombre trabajador y empeñoso, le agrada la sinceridad y el trato amable, es conviviente con Dalila, quien es ama de casa, y además tienen un hijo de 3 años de edad, y 4 primos. Juntos habitan en su casa propia. La actividad que realiza Carlos es la siembra de yuca para esto cuenta con un terreno de 25 hectáreas que compró hace 10 años, tiempo que viene realizando ésta actividad. Ahí tiene 02 hectáreas en producción de yuca más 03 hectáreas que están en proceso de sembrar. Adicionalmente a esto siembra arroz por temporada e incluso alquila el terreno a 200 nuevos soles por 01 hectárea producida. Pero para su propia actividad contrata el apoyo de hasta 05 peones para que lo ayuden en la siembra y cosecha de su producto acordando un pago diario de 20 nuevos soles a cada uno. Le gusta su vida de campo pues está acostumbrado vivir de esa manera  y además le genera ganancias para poder solventar los gastos de su hogar y brindarles una mejor calidad de vida. Al contrario comenta que no le agrada cuando se malogra su cosecha por alguna plaga, pero no se desanima y continúa trabajando. Tiene planes de seguir en su negocio y hacerlo crecer aumentando la producción de yuca. Este será el préstamo número 2 con la institución MFP. Por ello espera de su colaboración para que pueda concretar sus planes. Por otro lado se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas como en el crédito anterior. Con el monto solicitado de 1000 nuevos soles tiene planes de invertir en la siembra de  01 hectárea más de yuca para así ampliar su producción y poder atender la demanda de su producto.
texts.en: Carlos, a 33-year-old, is a diligent and industrious man.  He enjoys sincerity and fair dealing.  He lives with Delilah, who is a housewife, their 3-year-old son and 4 cousins.  Together they inhabit their own house.  The activity that Carlos carries out is the sowing of yucca.  For this he relies on 25 hectares of land that he bought 10 years ago.  He has carried out this activity since that time.  There are 2 hectares already in production of yucca and 3 more hectares that are in the process of being sown.  In addition to this he sows rice in season and even rents the land for 200 new soles per hectare.  But for his own activity he contracts the support of up to 5 laborers so that they can help with the sowing and harvesting of his crop, earning a daily payment of 20 new soles each.  He likes life in the field and is accustomed to living in this manner, besides which it generates him profits to be able to settle the household expenses and to offer his family a better quality of life.  On the contrary he says that it does not please him when he loses a crop to some plague, but he is not discouraged and continues working.  He has plans to continue in his business and to expand his production of yucca.  This will be his second  loan with the institution MFP.  He waits for the loans contribution so that he can finalize his plans.  On the other hand, he promises to comply with the payment schedule as he did on his previous loan.  With the requested total of 1000 new soles he has plans to invest in the sowing of 1 hectare more of yucca to  expand his production and to be able to attend to the demand for his product.

loans.use: to buy yucca seeds and contract laborers.

loans.name: Victor Francisco

texts.es:
El señor Victor Francisco es casado, tiene 37 años de edad, estudio los 3 años de educación primaria, tiene 4 hijos los cuales estudian, se dedica a la artesanía a la elaboración de sandalias para damas y niñas, inició este trabajo por iniciativa propia y hasta el momento lleva  9 años de experiencia.

Solicita un préstamo que lo utilizara para la compra de materiales como: piel, hilo, suelas, pegamento, etc. Espera en el futuro tener un negocio prospero.
texts.en: Victor Francisco is married, 37 years old and has a third-grade education. He has four children who are in school. He makes a living making hand-made sandals for women and children. He started the business on his own and has nine years of experience. He is requesting the loan to purchase supplies like leather, thread, soles, glue, etc. He hopes to have a prosperous business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase supplies to make sandals.

loans.name: “Lupita” Claudia Gua

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Lupita has a small grocery store. Her grandmother began this business when Lupita was a little girl, and opened this store selling just candies and crispy tortillas. But only a year later, her grandmother named her manager, and Lupita was the person in charge of the store. This meant that Lupita was the one responsible for the whole family’s expenses. The family members are: Lupita, her little four year old daughter and her grandmother. She is not divorced but has lived separated from her husband for some time now. Lupita manages the business and that includes supplying the store.

She is requesting a loan for $550.00 USD, payable in a term of 6-12 months. She wants to use this amount for supplies in her store, because in this season she has to be able to offer credit to her clients, who are facing a lot of expenses because of the new school period.

ESPAÑOL

La señora Lupita tiene un pequeño negocio de venta de abarrotes, este negocio lo inició su abuelita cuando ella era muy pequeña y solamente vendía dulces y tostadas, pero con el paso del tiempo se lo dejo a su cargo, ya que ella es la que se encarga de los gastos de su familia, la cual esta compuesta por su pequeña hija de 4 años y su Abuelita, pues esta separada de su esposo desde hace algún tiempo. Lupita es la que se encarga de surtir el negocio y de administrarlo.

Está solicitando un crédito por la cantidad de $ 550 USD a pagar en un plazo de 6 – 12 meses, para la compra de mercancía ya que en esta temporada tiene que darle crédito a sus clientes debido a que enfrentan muchos gastos por el regreso a clases de los niños.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Hamidulla

texts.en:
Hamidulla is 42, lives in Khaladj village, Salyan region. He is married and has 3 children. 
Every day he goes to the market and stores to offer his products.
This is his only source of income. 
Now he requests a loan of $1000 to buy a milk cow. He wants to improve his business o support the household expenses.
He is hard -working and has a humble family.
Hamidulla has had this business for 5 years.

loans.use: To buy a milk cow

loans.name: Selau

texts.en: The land is a gift from God, but making it productive it is up to the people to use it - this is what Selau believes.  She is married with one son and is a strong and active young lady.  She started with a small loan from SPBD and used it to buy weed killer and fertilizer for her farm where she grows taro, banana, taamu, yams, tomatoes, and cucumbers. Three days of the week she delivers her farm produce to the market.  Her husband helps her in her farm and they are very happy to work because it gives them more income. They are looking forward to obtaining another loan to buy a second-hand pick up truck for delivering their produce to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand pick up truck for delivery of farm produce to market

loans.name: Boris

texts.en:
Boris supports himself and his wife, Ida, by selling items for use in the home that everyone seems to need at one time or another. From matches, lighters and small tools to clocks, nails and glue--if a customer needs something small for use at home, Boris is likely to have it. He tries to maintain a large selection of items, and has developed a good reputation for running a shop where you can find what you need. His kiosk at the central market in Beregovo is in a good location that attracts customers.

Boris and his wife are facing some financial difficulties. Their home was damaged by a small earthquake, and the insurance company did not help them meet the cost of repairs as it should have. Boris is facing much higher out-of-pocket costs to fix the damage, and needs to generate more income from his business as he works to have his home repaired.

Boris has asked for a loan to help purchase new inventory. The type of business he runs experiences high product turnover, and the loan will help him buy a large number of new items to sell.

loans.use: Purchase inventory

loans.name: Luz

texts.es:
Business Description

Sra. Luz V. has a small store where she sells basic essentials. She started this business with savings from wages earned by her husband four years ago. Their daughters assist them in the shop.

Loan Use

Sra. V. will use this loan to purchase more merchandise at wholesale prices. She also wants to make some improvements to the space where her store is located

Personal Information

Sra. V. is 51 years old and has two children who are students. She has a stable family and her house is constructed from mixed materials. Her primary goal is to be able to increase her business so that she can be assured of being able to provide an education for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Kenney Molloy, Kiva volunteer

Descripción del Negocio

La Sra. Luz V. tiene una pequeña despensa donde vende todo tipo de Productos de primera necesidad, este negocio lo inicio con unos ahorros que hizo su esposo producto de un trabajo que realizo hace cuatro años. En el negocio le ayudan sus hijas

Uso del Préstamo

Ella necesita el crédito para realizar mas comprar de mercadería a precio de mayorista y quiere además realizar unas adecuaciones en el local donde tiene ubicada la despenda

Información Personal

Ella tiene 51 años y dos hijos que estudian su casa es de construcción mixta y tiene estabilidad familiar. Su principal meta es de poder progresar en su negocio para asegurar la educación de sus hijos

loans.use: Purchase more merchandise for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase merchandise sales

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Mrs. Chin M., age 38, works selling biscuits and foodstuffs, earning about $5 per day in revenue. She has no children. She would like to request a loan of $600 in order to purchase a trailer for her husband to attach to his motor-bike to start a transportation business. They expect he can earn up to $10 per day in revenue by transporting passengers. He is pictured in the photo on his motor-bike.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to attach to a motor-bike to start a passenger transportation business.

loans.name: Zahara

texts.en: My name is Zahara B. and I live with my family in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I am married with six children: four girls and two boys. My husband lives abroad and one of my sons runs a kiosk and sells various items such as candy, pulses, oils and other sundries. I would like to request a loan of $175 for my son to expand his kiosk.

loans.use: To expand the family kiosk business

loans.name: Shuhrat

texts.ru:
Shuhrat K., 56, is married and has 5 children. Shuhrat owns a taxi in Dushanbe. He plans to use this loan to purchase and install natural gas-based fuel system on his car. With gas prices rapidly rising, having natural gas-based engine would help Shuhrat save money on fuel and pass on the savings to his customers. Shuhrat plans to repay this loan within 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Кенджаев Хушвахт, возраст – 56 лет, образование – среднее, женат, имеет 5-х детей. Хушвахт имеет атомашину на которй работает по найму и в свободной от работы время подрабатывает, оказывакя услуги такси населению города Душанбе. Полученный кредит он хочет использовать на приобретение газового оборудования и установку его на свой автомобиль. Так как цены на бензин растут очень быстро, также и цена за проезд растёт. Данный кредит поможет ему установить газовое оборудование и снизить цену на проезд в такси всем жителям Душанбе, которые захотят воспользоваться услугами такси. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 6 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase and install natural gas-based fuel system

loans.name: Maria Isabel

texts.es:
María belongs to the communal bank "Las Hormiguitas," located in Yarinacocha, Ucayali in Peru. She the 36-year-old mother of three children, and her husband is a driver. With the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for S./300 soles, she decided to invest in a small business selling automobile spare parts.

Currently, she relies on that store selling spare parts retail and wholesale. She gets up at 6am to see to her children, prepare the food, and tend her store with the help of her husband.

With this loan for $625, which she will repay in four months, she will invest in buying parts such as tires, belts, filters, brakes, headlights, electronic systems, horns, etc.

María is content and grateful because, thanks to the support from Manuel Ramos, she was able to open a business and work independently.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora María pertenece al banco comunal Las Hormiguitas, ubicado en el Jr. Bolognesi Mz. LL Lt. 16, distrito de Yarinacocha, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 36 años, es madre de 3 hijos y su esposo es chofer. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300 decide invertir en un pequeño negocio de venta de repuestos de autos.

En la actualidad cuenta con una tienda donde vende sus repuestos para autos al por mayor y menor. Se levanta a las 6 a.m. para atender a sus hijos, preparar la comida y atender su tienda con la ayuda de su esposo.

Con el préstamo de S/.1,800, el cual pagará en 4 meses, invertirá en la compra de repuestos como llantas, fajas, filtros, frenos, focos, sistemas eléctricos, bocinas, etc.

Maria se siente tranquila y agradecida porque gracias al poyo de Manuela Ramos pudo poner un negocio y trabajar de forma independiente.

loans.use: Purchase additional spare parts for her auto parts store.

loans.name: Maura's Group

texts.es:
Maura, Teodora, and Delia have been members of the Los Claveles communal bank for 11, 10, and 10 years respectively.

Maura is a 59-year-old married mother of 8. She has a mini market and liquor store in her home. She also knits bedspreads, embroiders sheets, and does other handicrafts that she sells to friends and family.

Teodora is a 31-year-old single mother of one child. She buys tara pods, and cochineal insects in her district of residence, Pacaycasa, then sells her products to middlemen in the city of Lima.

Delia is a 55-year-old widow with 2 children. She sells wholesale meat to the markets of Ayacucho. She buys her livestock throughout various markets in the region.

Maura, Teodora, and Delia need loans of 1000, 600, and 600 Peruvian soles respectively, which will be invested in the purchase of cooking oil, noodles, rice, milk, sugar, tara pods, cochineal insects, and pork.

Maura, Teodora, and Delia dream of providing an education for their children, seeing them become professionals, expanding their businesses, and building their own house.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Maura, Teodora y Delia pertenecen al Banco Comunal Los Claveles hace 11, 10, 10 años respectivamente.

Maura es casada, tiene 59 años y 8 hijos, Maura tiene una tienda de abarrotes y licores en su casa. Además Maura teje colchas, borda sabanas, entre otras manualidades que vende a amigos y familiares.

Por otro lado Teodora es madre soltera, tiene 31 años y 1 hijo, Teodora compra tara y cochinilla en el distrito donde vive, Pacaycasa, y lo vende a intermediarios que llevan a la ciudad de Lima.

Mientras que Delia es viuda, tiene 55 años y 2 hijos, Delia vende carne al por mayor a los mercados de la ciudad de Ayacucho, los animales los compra en la diferentes ferias de la región.

Maura, Teodora y Delia necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 600 soles, 600 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de aceite, fideo, arroz, leche, azúcar, tara, cochinilla, cerdo.

Los sueños de Maura, Teodora y Delia son que sus hijos estudien y sean profesionales, tener una negocio más grande y construir su casa.

loans.use: Purchase of cooking oil, noodles, rice, milk, sugar, tara pods, cochineal insects, and pigs

loans.name: Dora

texts.es:
Dora is a member of the Mujeres Dinamicas ("Dynamic Women") community bank. She lives in the Peruvian "region" of San Marin and her shop is located in her house. She sells groceries, snacks and other everyday items. She used to work as a nutritionist in a hospital and then as a meat vendor, her first foray into the world of business. She decided to remodel a room in her house where she set up her shop. She saw, wisely as it turned out, that there were no businesses like hers in the neighborhood. With the S/.2000 loan, to be repaid in 6 months, she will buy eggs, canned fish, rice, sugar, cooking oil and other products for her shop.

Dora is married and has 4 children. Her husband supports her completely and they will soon be able to open a "polleria" (a shop for selling chicken) and a "chifa" (a Peruvian word for a Chinese food restaurant) that their daughter will run.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Dora D. V., es socia del Banco Comunal Mujeres Dinamicas, vive en la Region San Marin, Provincia de Picota y distrito de Picota, su bodega está ubicada en su propia casa situado en la Av. Marginal carretera Fernanco Belaunde Terri, vende abarrotes en general, golosinas y otros productos comestibles de soncumo diario. Antes trabajaba en el hospital como nutricionista, luedo se dedicó a vender carnes rojas, chorizo, cecina y comuda iniciándose así en el mundo del negocio. Decide acondicionar en su casa un ambiente donde implementó su bodega, además con buena visión vio que en la zona no había un negocio como el de ella. Con el préstamo de S/. 2000.00 el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará huevos en javas, distintas variedades de conservas de pescado en cajas,arroz, azúcar en sacos, aceite en litros, además de sutir con productos de aseo para el hogar y personal.

Ella es casada y tiene 4 hijos, su esposo la apoya siempre en el negocio, juntos podrán muy pronto una pollería y un chifa el cual estará administrado por su hija , y así asegurar el bienestar de su familia.

loans.use: Buy merchanidse for resale.

loans.name: Aplonia

texts.es:
First loan:

http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=27118&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Apolonia joined the Primavera ("Spring") community bank 8 years ago. She is 54 years old and married with 6 children, 2 of whom live with her. She makes her living as a street vendor, selling snacks on a main street of Ayacucho near a high school. She has a cart from which she sells her snacks.

Apolonia needs a loan of 2000 soles, money that she will use to buy cookies, candy, gum, and chocolates, for her business. She will also use part of the loan to pay her daughter's school fees.

Apolonia's savings will be set asiD. for future emergencies and she dreams that her sales will get better and better, that her children continue their studies and find professional careers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Primer préstamo:

http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=27118&_tpos=1&_tpg=1

Apolonia pertenece al Banco Comunal Primavera hace 8 años. Apolonia es casada, tiene 54 años y 6 hijos D. los cuales 2 viven con ella, Apolonia venD. golosinas D. manera ambulatoria en una calle céntrica D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho cerca D. un colegio D. menores. Sus ventas lo realiza en una carretilla.

Apolonia necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra D. galletas, caramelos, chicles, chocolates y parte del préstamo para los gastos D. educación D. su hija.

Sus ahorros lo utilizara en alguna emergencia y los sueños D. Apolonia son que sus ventas mejoren, que sus hijos estudien y sean profesionales.

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

loans.name: Vera

texts.en:
Vera M. is married and has three children. The money she was making in her previous job was not enough to support the basic needs of her family. Therefore, Vera decided to start her own business. For the last 12 years, she has had a vending kiosk selling women’s clothing in the central market. It is the only source of income for her family. 

Vera realizes the value of lending services which have contributed to the growth and success of her small business. She has maintained a perfect credit history with “Nadiya Ukraine,” repaying all of her loans. Currently, Vera is requesting a loan of US$875 to buy assorted inventory. One of her long-term plans is to develop a sustainable venture that she could leave for her children when they grow up. She believes that her optimism and tenacity, combined with external financial assistance, will continue to improve her business and its profitability.

loans.use: Purchase of summer dresses for retail sale

loans.name: Sambath

texts.en: Mrs. Sambath T. lives in Preak Thom Village in Kandal Province, where she is the 49-year-old mother of five children, one of whom is working as a construction worker while three others are attending school. The youngest one is of preschool age. Mrs. Sambath T. owns a small restaurant where she serves lunch. Since her business has improved, she wants to expand it through a loan to purchase additional ingredients to cook more delicious meals for her customers. Her husband, Mr. Chantha Saom, is a construction worker. Mrs. Sambath T. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients to cook more delicious food for her customers.

loans.name: Cleopatra

texts.en:
Cleopatra is 34 years old, married and has two children ages 7 and 2. She is currently in business selling cosmetics from a small shop which she opened five years ago. She works from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. every day, and is able to make a monthly profit of about $230.

In the past, Cleopatra took out a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania and used it to increase her capital. She is applying for a new loan to buy clothes to sell to her customers.

loans.use: to buy clothing to sell to her customers

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali M. is a 25-year-old father of one daughter. He has been raising sheep for meat production since 2006. He lives in an Internally Displaced People settlement in the Bilasuvar region.

Even since he was very little, Ali has been around people raising animals, and thanks to his knowledge, he dedicates himself to raising and selling sheep. Now his skills and experience bring stability to his very young family. He has one wish: to see at least one of his children continuing the family business, and now he is trying to make his business profitable for the future. Right now he has applied for 1200 USD to purchase 20 sheep for 60 USD each. Let's be the ones who reach out our hands to help Ali!

loans.use: To purchase 20 sheep

loans.name: Diab

texts.fr: DIAB F. EVOLUE DANS LE SECTEUR DE L'ELEVAGE DEPUIS 2001. SON ACTIVITE CONSISTE A ACHETER DES CHEVRES, LES ENGRAISSE ET LES REVENDE DANS LE MARCHE.
texts.en:
DIAB F. has been progressing in the livestock sector since 2001. His work consists of buying goats, fattening them, and reselling them at market.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fattening sheep and goats

loans.name: Nazakat

texts.en:
Nazakat I. was born in 1982 and is the mother of two children. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan Kalbadjar region. Nazakat is in the Khirdalan settlement.

Nazakat has run her business for six years, and needs a loan of 970 AZN to buy additional foodstuffs.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Rocio

texts.es: Rocio tiene 35 años de edad, es madre de 2 niños que estudian, vive junto a su conviviente quien siempre le da la mano en sus labores. Ella tiene un pequeño molino donde fabrica alimentos para pollos (purina), esta actividad la viene haciendo desde 4 años atrás, y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que conoce a mucha gente con quienes imparte ideas de negocio mientras realiza sus ventas. Le es rentable porque su pequeño molino le produce más de lo que se podría imaginar, además será una de las primeras exportadoras de este producto en su zona, por lo que le va  muy bien. Este es su 5to préstamo con MFP, y ha demostrado ser responsable con sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita comprará más insumos para la fabricación de su producto.
texts.en:
Rocio is 35 years old, is mother to two children who are studying, and lives together with her spouse who always gives her a hand with her work. She has a small mill where she manufactures chicken feed (purina), and has been doing this work for four years. What she likes about her work is that she gets to know many people who give her business ideas while she carries out her sales. The business is profitable because her small mill produces more for her than she could have imagined, and furthermore she will be one of the first exporters of this product in her zone, so it is going very well. This is her fifth loan with MFP and she has shown herself to be responsible with her payments. With the money she is requesting she will buy more raw ingredients to manufacture her product.

Translated from Spanish by Diane Lister, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase raw ingredients to make her product

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 38-year-old Happiness M. from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children ages two and seven years old. Happiness has been running a pharmacy since 2001. A pharmacy in Tanzania is traditionally a small store that has many glass shelves in which a variety of medicines are displayed, from antibiotic soap to malaria medicine. She works at the business for 13-16 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. She is requesting a loan of 750 USD in order to increase her inventory. Happiness thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Ghulam Bahodin Najrabi Group

texts.en:
Fareema is the group leader of Ghulam Bahodin Najrabi group. They all live in 17th district and each of them would like to take the loan for their own business. The total amount of their group loan is 40,000 Afghani (USD$850) for the term of 8 months.

Fareema wants to take a loan for quilt sewing. Zarmina wants to take a loan for leather sewing. Hasina for sewing clothes and Zarghona for buying materials for her brother’s cart.

They are confident that with the money they receive they can have a good profit and run their business in a good way. They all are happy about the loan process of loan.

loans.use: To improve her quilt sewing business.

loans.name: Sandra Patricia

texts.es:
La señora Sandra Patricia C. es madre soltera y tiene bajo su responsabilidad ha dos hijos que actual mente están estudian y quiere lo mejor para ellos.
A la vivienda le está haciendo falta la barda, pero en este momento no cuenta con el capital necesario para comprar el material y pagar la mano de obra. Es por eso que solicita un préstamo para poder realizar la mejora y así darles la seguridad a sus hijos ya que ella trabaja casi todo el día en una fabrica en el departamento de producción. Planea pagar esté crédito con los ingresos de su empleo.
texts.en:
Ms. Sandra Patricia C. is a single mother of 2 children. Her children are still in school and she wants the best for them. At her home, the only thing missing is a wall in front of the house. At this time she does not have the money to buy the materials and pay for the work. That’s why she is asking for a loan to complete the home improvement project and provide security for her children. She works almost all day in the production department of a factory and she plans on paying back the loan with the income from her job.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building a wall in front of her home

loans.name: Lilian J.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 30 year old Lilia M. from Mbeya. She is married with 2 children, between the ages of 1 month and 2 years old. Lilian has been running Agricultural Inputs since 2006. Her business purchases agricultural equipment in wholesale bases and sells them to farmers in retail bases.

She works at the business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by her husband. Lilian currently earns about 188USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan of 800USD in order to purchase more agricultural equipment in bulk for reselling. In the future, she plans to open the same business at another location. Lilian thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more agricultural equipment in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Iokapeta

texts.en:
Iokapeta S., 34, is married with one child. She has been growing and selling vegetables for two years. She sells to the general public seven days per week. She is seeking a loan to purchase a wheelbarrow, vegetable seeds such as cabbage, tomato, cucumber, etc., fertilizer, weed eater, and gloves for weeding.

This is her first loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 125 Tala ($44 USD). An SPBD loan is Iokapeta’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan through traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase a wheelbarrow, vegetable seeds, fertilizer, weed eater, and gloves for weeding.

loans.name: Abavi Coco

texts.fr: Cette dame  et une résidente du quartier de Nétimé qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de sacs de sortie pour dame en détail, elle exerce ce commerce au grand marché de Lomé et achète ses marchandises de l’Europe et aussi de l’Asie. Elle a beaucoup de clients parce qu’elle vend des chaussures de bonne qualité. Elle exerce ce commerce depuis 2005. Son stock actuel de marchandises ne lui permet pas de satisfaire sa clientèle, elle sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 50 sacs de sorties dame de grande qualité.
texts.en:
This lady is a resident of the Nétimé neighborhood, an outlying district of the town of Lomé. She earns a living selling handbags for ladies; she has her sales point in the big open-air market of Lomé and buys her merchandise from Europe and also from Asia. She has many customers because she has good quality wares. She has been in this business since 2005. Her present stock of merchandise does not allow her to satisfy the demand of her clientele, so she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 50 excellent quality women's handbags.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of women's handbags for re-sale

loans.name: Khekh Niakk 23 Group

texts.fr: CE GROUPEMENT EST COMPOSE DE DEUX HOMMES ET TROIS FEMMES QUI SONT DES VOISINS AU QUARTIER DIAMAGUENE DE THIES.ILs font du petit commerce et vendent en général des denrées alimentaires, des habits et des téléphones portables.avec ce groupe de solidarité ,ILs envisagent de contracter un pret pour renforcer leurs fonds de roulement et améliorer leurs revenus .
texts.en:
This group is composed of 2 men and 3 women who are neighbors in the Diamaguene district of Thies. They are petty traders and in general, they sell groceries, clothing, and cell phones. As members of this solidarity group, they hope to take out a loan to increase their working capital and their income.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: retail businesses

loans.name: Olushola

texts.en: Olushola is 39-years old and married with four children. She is in the business of selling fruits, and she is requesting a loan in order to increase her inventory which will enable her to service more customers and to increase her income. Olushola says thank you to KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is thirty-five years old, married, and currently has no child. She lives with her husband in a rented apartment in a commercial town called Dwenase in the Western Region. Her husband is a farmer.

Mary trades in utensils. She buys her goods from Kumasi at affordable prices and sells at the market square in her community. She treks to other markets to sell as well. Mary has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk. She aspires to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy utensils in bulk

loans.name: Loh's Group

texts.en: This small loan is for only two borrowers. Its leader, Mr. Loh S., 38 years old, is a motorbike taxi driver. He uses his old motor to pick up his customers who need to go anywhere around his community. He is married with five teenage children; two of them are employed as security guards for an industry and provide income to meet their family’s expense, while his wife works sewing clothing to earn a living. Loh S. cannot attract as many clients as before because his motor breaks down frequently, so he hopes to replace this old one by using the Kiva loan to purchase a new one. One other borrower, Mrs. Meur P., is applying for a loan to use as additional capital in her fish-selling business.

loans.use: To replace an old motor

loans.name: Pasos Firmes Group 3

texts.en:
Maria F. is 39 years old and owns her own home decorating and accessories business in the sugarcane community (called a "batey") of La Gina, which lies in the eastern part of the Dominican Republic. Today Maria will take out a new loan - her seventh one to date with Kiva and Esperanza International - so she can buy new merchandise, such as bedsheets, curtains, tablecoths, silverware, artificial flowers, and assorted ceramic decorative pieces for her store. Once her loan is funded, Maria will travel over three hours by bus to buy her merchandise in the capital city of Santo Domingo, and she will then sell her wares in her own community and in neighboring bateys.

The revenues from Maria's in-home enterprise are crucial to the well-being of her family. Along with her husband's earnings from cultivating and harvesting sugarcane, Maria's business supports six dependents, including four of her own children (ages 18, 16, and 15) and two nephews (ages 7 and 4). All of Maria's children attend school, and she hopes to be able to send them to the university some day. Maria recognizes the connection between the success of her business and the opportunities available to her children. She hopes her business will grow so that her children and nephews might have a better life. Currently, opportunities for socioeconomic mobility in the batey communities are scarce. The bateys are generally geographically isolated, and, because a majority of batey residents are of Haitian descent, they often face great challenges obtaining citizenship and other political rights in the Dominican Republic.

Maria is a member of Group 3 in the Pasos Firmes (Solid Steps) Bank of Hope. In the accompanying photograph of the borrowers in Pasos Firmes Group 3, she is second from the right.

loans.use: New merchandise for home decorating and accessories store

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Lina L. is a 38-year-old woman living in the town of Vavau. She is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Lina owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Lina has been engaged in this business for over four years and earns approximately 500 WST a month.

In 2003, Lina joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1600 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase new equipment and tools in order to expand the business. Lina is now requesting a new loan of 2300 WST which will be used to invest in renovating the business. The loan will be her fourth loan from SPBD. Lina plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Business renovations

loans.name: Rizzalyne

texts.en:
Rizzalyne is a retailer of vegetables and mushrooms in their village. She sells their own harvested mushrooms in their backyard since it is the main product produced in their village in Isidro, Paredes, Diffun, Quirino aside from rice. She hopes to receive a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 as additional capital for her mushroom production and for her to further improve her vending business of vegetables.

She is already 25 years old and married to Arleen D. C.. The couple is gifted with two children namely: Rizza Mae - 8 years old and Yvan - 5 years old Both are enrolled in a public school in their village. She hopes that they will be able to continue their studies.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
La señora  Maruja es socia del  Banco Comunal “Nueva Flor”  que esta ubicado en el distrito de Ilave, Provincia de El Collao, Departamento de Puno, ella tiene 25 años de edad, estado civil casada y es madre de 3 hijos y no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar es iletrada, vive en el centro poblado Rosa Cami comunidad de Llanque Inamaya.

La señora trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace  mas de 1 año, su préstamo inicial fue de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, para la compra de ganado ovino.

En este momento ella solicito un préstamo de S/. 700.00 Nuevos soles, este dinero lo invertirá en la compra de ganado ovino para engorde, Maruja también vende productos de la región en la ferias semanales.

Su mayor deseo poder darles una profesión a sus hijos.

A ella le gustan las facilidades en los préstamos y losa ahorros
texts.en:
Mrs. Maruja is a member of the "Nueva Flor" Community Bank which is located in the district of Ilave, Province of El Collao, Puno State. She is 25 years old, married and the mother of 3 children. She did not have an opportunity to go to school so she is illiterate. She lives in the village of Rosa Cami, Llanque Inamaya community.

Mrs. Maruja has been working with Manuela Ramos association for more than a year. Her initial loan was for 500 nuevos soles that she invested in the purchase of sheep.

She is asking for a loan of,$250 money that will be invested in the purchase of sheep for fattening. Maruja also sells products from the region in the farmers market.

Her greatest desire is to give her children a college education. She likes the terms of the loans and saving.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital.

loans.name: Rodney

texts.en:
Rodney started his sheet metal business, C. Sheet Metal, in 2007 after having worked with his uncle for ten years in the same industry.

In a short period of time, Rodney grew his business into a successful enterprise. He considers himself a fighter; he has acquired numerous contracts and has expanded his business despite the downturn in the economy. Today, he needs $10,000 to finance more growth and to purchase inventory.

In the future, Rodney hopes to keep his business growing, with the goal of hiring others to create jobs in his community. After being denied at his bank for a line of credit because of his credit score, he is relieved to know that there are organizations out there that trust his abilities and are willing to give him a chance.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok R., 28, lives with his wife and one young child in the Takeo province. They both work in a garment factory. Additionally, his wife, San Chreb, also raises pigs to earn extra income and thus raise their standard of living. Combined, they typically make about US $2 of profit every day. Sok R. is asking for a loan of US $600 so that his wife can raise more pigs. (Sok’s wife is pictured at home.)

loans.use: raising pigs

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn B. is from the village of Mialem. She is 37 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sand and gravel business. Merlyn's main source of income comes from selling construction materials in the local community. She has been in business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Merlyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business. Merlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This loan will be her sixth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 
----------------------
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase inventory and working capital.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es: La señora Gloria es una mujer dinámica y colaboradora, vive en el distrito de Callería región de Ucayali, tiene 47 años y es madre de seis hijos de los cuales dos son menores de edad. Ella presta servicio de cochera y lavado de vehículos, su esposo es carpintero. Forma parte del Banco Comunal “Carmen Cabrejos” desde hace tres años, el primer crédito que obtuvo fue de 300 soles que utilizó para invertir en la compra de golosinas y venderlos en su casa. En la actualidad Gloria requiere un crédito de 1500 soles que invertirá en la compra de una bomba de agua para su lavadero.  La meta de Gloria es tener una pollería ya que ese es el sueño de su vida y con esfuerzo y perseverancia lo conseguirá.
texts.en:
Gloria, 47, is a dynamic, cooperative woman who lives in the Callería district, Ucayali region. She is the mother of six children, two of whom are still minors. She runs a garage and car wash; her husband is a carpenter. For the past three years she has been a member of the "Carmen Cabrejos" communal bank. Her first, 300 sol loan, was used to buy snacks to sell from home. Currently, Gloria needs a 1,500 sol loan to buy a water pump for her laundry room. Gloria's goal is to have a poultry shop since this has been her life's dream and with effort and perseverance she will reach it.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a water pump for her laundry room.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James M. has owned and run an electronics repair shop called Line Electronics Repair for two years. He was previously employed in a similar repair shop and ultimate went out on his own. He fixes radios, TVs, DVD players, amplifiers and antennae. Line Electronics is a secure stall located in a mixed use area in Spaki / Majengo, a neighborhood in Mombasa. His business is a mix of 2/3rds new customers and 1/3 repeat business. He struggles when clients do not have the cash to pick up their repaired items and when he has to get spare parts from Nairobi.

James is using this KES 20,000 loan to expand his offering and sell car stereos, both new and used, and new cable / antenna wire. James' goal for his business is to expand the shop and offer more spare parts and wider repair services. He is not married yet and his goal is to have his own house. His customers say he is smart in his work (he gets referrals when other technicians have failed) and hard-working.

loans.use: To expand product offering to include car stereos, antenna and cable wire

loans.name: Lalaine

texts.en: Lalaine P. is from the village of Talacogon, Lugait, Misamis Oriental. She is 30 years old, is married, and has one school-aged child. Lalaine owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Lalaine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma L. is 26 years old. She has a farm. Her main crop is rice because people in their village are constantly buying it for food for their respective families. She has two children. Her eldest is only 6 years old. She dreams of sending her children to school until they reach college so that when they are older they will land a better job. 

She is asking a loan of PHP 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will go far in buying farm supplies to grow her harvest and her income.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more charcoal in bulk.

loans.name: Lorena

texts.es: Lorena C. G. de 30 años de edad, reside en San Luis Talpa, ubicado en el departamento de La Paz. Vive junto a sus dos pequeños hijos, los cuales dependen por completo de ella. Lorena posee una tienda en la cual comercializa productos perecederos y de primera necesidad, entre los cuales están: pan, leche, verduras, detergentes, entre otros productos más. Así mismo ella se encarga de vender ropa para niños, hombres y mujeres, lo cual le permite obtener algunas ganancias extras. Para Lorena es de mucha importancia el poder obtener ganancias aceptables, de su negocio, debido a que esta es la única fuente de ingresos con los que cuenta para poder brindarles todo lo necesario a sus dos hijos, ya que ella es madre soltera quien no recibe ningún tipo de ayuda económica para la manutención de ellos. Lorena solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda surtir la tienda no solo con productos comestibles y de primera necesidad para el hogar, sino también para invertir en papelería y cuadernos, ya que en los alrededores de su negocio no existe ninguna librería. Lorena cuenta con la ilusión de poder brindarle una vida mejor a su familia, en un hogar en el cual este suplido de todas las necesidades básicas.
texts.en:
30-year old Lorena C. G. lives in San Luis Talpa which is in La Paz department. She lives with her two small children who are completely dependent on her. Lorena owns a store selling perishables and basic necessities such as bread, milk, vegetables, detergent, etc. She also sells clothing for children and adults, a job that provides her with additional income. In Lorena’s view, it is very important to be able to earn an adequate income as she is the sole breadwinner and has to provide everything for her children. She is a single mother who does not receive any kind of financial help for their upbringing. Lorena is asking for a loan to buy more stock for her store. Not only does she want to sell perishables and basic necessities, but also stationery and exercise books as there is no bookstore near her business. Her dream is to provide a better life for her family in a home that has all the essentials.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy perishables and stationery

location.town: San Luis Talpa,  departamento de La Paz.

loans.name: Salokhidin

texts.ru: Шахобов Салохидин проживает в районе Шахринав. Возраст, 41 год. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Салохидин разводит крупно- рогатый скот у себя дома. Этим видом деятельности он занимается более 4 лет. До этого он работал мастером в мастерской. Кредит берет для закупа скота. Салохидин хочет приобрести мелкий рогатый скот. Этим он старается увеличить свой доход.
texts.en:
Salokhidin S. lives in the Shahrinav region. He is 41 years old; married with 4 children. His wife is a housewife. Salokhidin raises livestock at home. He has been in this business for over 4 years. Before that he worked as a master in a workshop. Salokhidin is requesting the loan to purchase livestock. He wants to purchase sheep and goats. By this he hopes to increase his income.

Translated from Russian by Anna Melyakova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase cattle

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is a widow with six children. She is 60 years old and she is a grandmother. Life as a widow has been very challenging to her and the family. She sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She uses her years of experience in business to attract and retain more customers. She hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Kira Development Group, Mukono

texts.en:
S. Agnes appears in the small photo at the bottom left of the group photo just like in the group photo itself. She is 37 years old and is the mother of six school-going children.

Agnes’s business preoccupation for the last eight years has been rearing poultry and selling agricultural produce as well as being a farmer and selling what she grows. She operates in Kira, Mukono district.

Agnes envisages a situation where her weekly profit of 50,000 shillings will be increased if she gets this loan. With the profits, she plans on buying more poultry and buying more land to plant more crops.

Agnes says constant poultry diseases and fluctuating prices at the local markets of agricultural produce have been her major problems. She is grateful that she obtains loans that stand in for her in case of need.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and their feed and more produce to sell

loans.name: Magdalena's Group

texts.en:
Magdalena G. is from the village of Larion Alto, Tuguegarao City. She is 48 years old. Magdalena is the leader of a 11-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Magdalena is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Magdalena owns and operates a tailoring business where she provides general  alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Magdalena has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Magdalena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Magdalena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Magdalena is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This will be Magdalena's eighth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her house. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Build a room

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en: Gemma J. is from the village of Brgy. Villaros, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 34 years old. Gemma is married and has three infant children. To make a living, Gemma runs a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of fruits in the local community. Gemma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Gemma joined ASKI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Gemma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Phallen

texts.en:
Mrs. Phallen K., 30 years old, and her husband, Mr. Vi Kang, also 30 years old, have been married for two years and have one young daughter. Besides her daughter, she also has her parents living with her. They are living on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  

Phallen has been selling groceries for ten years. She buys grocery items from Oreysey market located in Phnom Penh for resale in front of her house. Her husband is a motor taxi driver. 

Phallen is applying for a loan of US$ 1,000 to purchase more grocery items for resale and she also will use a part of the loan to repair the house where she lives.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for resale and repair her house

loans.name: Fredny Angelito

texts.es:
Fredny de 42 años, vive en la Perimetral de Guayaquil (perímetro periurbano, que tiene una ecología en disolución). Tiene un taller de mecánica llamado “B.” 

Aunque al principio fue muy difícil tener su propio taller para poder mantener a su mama el tuvo que trabajar muy fuerte haciendo puertas, ventanas, rejas etc. Ahora el tiene su propio taller de cerrajería, trabaja con personas que contrata.      

Para continuar con su negocio el quiere comprar con el préstamo cemento, piedras para adecuar mejor su negocio. En el futuro quiere construir una casa para alquilar departamentos.
texts.en:
Fredny is 42 years old and lives on the perimeter of Guayaquil (the suburbs that are somewhat rural in nature). He has mechanical workshop called “B.”. From the beginning it has been difficult to be a business owner. He has to support his mother. In order to support her he works hard each day making doors, windows, screens, etc. Now he has his own locksmith business also. He works with people that hire him. In order to continue with this business he would like to buy, with this loan, cement and stones. In this way he can improve his business. In the future he would like to build a house and rent out the rooms.

Translated from Spanish by Esther Levandoski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: doors, screens

loans.name: Sabarnor Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Sabarnor” group. They are small-scale businesswomen based in Makeni, a city in Northern Sierra Leone. These small-scale entrepreneurs have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each from SMT/Kiva lenders in order to improve their businesses. 
 
The leader of this group is Fatmata K. who is pictured on the left in the first row.  Fatmata was born in Makeni.  She is approximately 26 years old and married with four children – two in primary school and two not of school-going age.
 
Fatmata makes a living by selling clothes, rubber bowls and slippers. With her four years of experience in this business, Fatmata will use her share of this loan to buy bales of clothes, dozens of slippers and rubber bowls to add to her business.

loans.use: To buy bales of clothes, dozens of slippers and rubber bowls

loans.name: Estelle Rajy

texts.fr:
Femme de 32ans, celibataire et mère d'un enfant agée d'une annee,  ayant arrete  ses études en terminale et n'ayant plus de soutien financier elle se lance dans le commerce en 2009. son revenu varie de 8000frs à 10000frs par jour.
A l'octroi de son pret , elle compte approvisionner son stock en ajoutant des cartons de viande, poissons frais,volailles, condiments, cartons de tomate ,bidon d'huile...
Elle s'approvisionne dans les chambres froides et marches de la place, toujours pret a reserver un bon accueil a ses clients, offrrir ses meilleurs services, faire des prix abordables, et respecter les heures d'ouverture de son resto.
Elle l'avenir elle pense ouvrir un grand restaurant et epargner plus, pour  soutenir son enfant et acheter un terrain .
texts.en:
Estelle Rajy B. is 32 years old, single, and mother of a one-year old child. Having stopped her studies in final year of secondary school and being without financial support she threw herself into commerce in 2009. Her income varies from 8000 frs to 10000frs a day. When granted a loan, she intends to increase her supplies and buy meat, fresh fish, poulty, condiments, boxes of tomatoes, cans of oil etc. She gets her supplies from the local coldrooms and markets, and always offers a warm welcome to her clients, providing the best service at affordable prices, and respecting the opening hours of her small restaurant. In the future she would like to open a big restaurant and save more, to support her child and buy a plot of land.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: achat des cartons de poissons, viande, volailles,

loans.name: Shamim Begum's Group

texts.en:
Shamim Begum is a wife of A. D.. They reside in a city in Pakistan called Multan, which is famous for its history and warm weather. Her husband is involved in the boutique business. He displays his handmade dresses with different designs in his boutique. To complete the dresses, Shamim also supports him so he is able to display new designs of clothes and attract more customers. 
 
He started this business a few years ago from savings and started earning well. Basically, his boutique is placed in a market that is always filled with heavy crowds and being a part of that place, he has to keep his boutique up-to-date with the latest fashions in clothes. 
 
Therefore, Shamim has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s boutique. With the loan amount, he will buy items such as cloth, beads, laces and tassels in bulk, which will enable him to make more dresses to display in his boutique.
 
She is very much hopeful that this investment will prove best for her husband’s business. He will be able to generate good profit on it and improve the living standard of the family.

loans.use: Purchase the required items in bulk for boutique business

loans.name: Marthe Ablawa

texts.fr: Z. H. Marthe Ablawa est née en 1958 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Marthe Ablawa vit depuis une vingtaine d'année au quartier Djèdjèlayé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, avec sa famille. Marthe Ablawa est mariée à ALI Yérima Sanni et est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Marthe Ablawa vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui, les différentes charges de la famille, grâce au revenu que lui procure son activité. Marthe Ablawa a arrêté les classes au cours secondaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Marthe Ablawa mène comme activité, la vente de fournitures scolaires et de façon secondaire, la vente de cartes de recharges téléphoniques. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Marthe Ablawa achète ses produits. Marthe Ablawa exerce cette activité depuis une vingtaine d'année et a déjà obtenu cinq crédits auprès de ALIDé, avec un bon remboursement. En vue de renforcer son activité pour mieux préparer la rentrée scolaire et vendre suffisamment ses produits, Marthe Ablawa sollicite à nouveau, un prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Marthe Ablawa Z. H. was born in 1958 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Marthe Ablawa has lived for some twenty years in the Djèdjèlayé neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, with her family. Marthe Ablawa is married to Yerima Sanni Ali and is the mother of three children, all in school. Marthe Ablawa helps out her husband and, along with him, assures that the needs of her family are met, thanks to the revenue brought in by her business. Marthe Ablawa left school at the high-school level. To meet her needs, Marthe Ablawa runs a business selling school furniture and as a secondary business, sells rechargeable telephone cards. It is at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, that Marthe Ablawa sells her products. Marthe Ablawa has run this business for some 20 years and has already obtained 5 loans from ALIDé, having paid back the others well. With the goal of strengthening her business to better prepare for the start of the school year and to sell a sufficient amount of her products, Marthe Ablawa is once again requesting a loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy school furniture and rechargeable telephone cards

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en: Janeth A. is a 29-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures: motorcycle transport, food vending and a general store. She lives in Barangay Bulwang, Mabinay, Negros Oriental. Janeth has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her motorcycle transportation, food vending and general store businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly profit of PHP 3,600. Janeth is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can purchase spare parts to maintain the passenger tricycle shown in the photo. This will be her 7th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Janeth aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts to maintain her passenger tricycle

loans.name: Zoila

texts.en:
Zoila is a single, 53-year-old mother of five who lives with three of her own children, a daughter-in-law and four nieces in Tibas, located in the central valley of Costa Rica. 

Zoila runs a store out of her home. As you can see in the picture, she has a window that opens onto the street which is used to interact with customers. Zoila sells all kinds of products including plantains, milk, soft drinks, candies, etc. She hopes to use this loan to finance the purchase of diverse merchandise (including the products listed above) in order to fill her store and attract more customers. 

Zoila travels three times a week to the market in order to stock up on inventory. On these days, she must wake up at 3:00 AM in order to make a trip to the market and open her store by 6:00 AM. Zoila takes a lunch break at 12:30 PM until her niece arrives at 1:00 PM. At this point, her niece carries out domestic tasks while Zoila continues with the business of running the store. Zoila closes the store at 8:00 PM. 

Zoila´s main obstacle is a lack of access to working capital. She hopes this loan will help her to increase capital and finance the purchase of more items to sell in her store.

loans.use: For the purchase of inventory items (milk, plantains, soft drinks).

loans.name: Mike

texts.en:
Mike is a single man who lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is house rent.  

He has been operating M-pesa (mobile money transfer services) for the last year. His potential customers are the town dwellers and passersby. Mike faces the major challenge of competition because of the many shops with similar products. Mike hopes to open at least three more mobile money transfer shops.

With the Kshs 20,000, he wants to purchase airtime scratch cards and purchase a photocopier machine. He decided to join Yehu because of its good reputation in the community.

loans.use: To purchase airtime scratch cards and a photocopier machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Build a fence in front of home

loans.name: Cesar Silverio

texts.es: El Sr.Cesar tiene 43 años de edad, el es soltero cuenta con casa propia el cual heredo de su madre, el vive solo, en Av. Paris en el Distrito de La tinguiña, en casa de material de adobe de un piso. El se dedica  a la venta de ropa como ambulante en el mercado La Union, y los dias sabados y domingos como recorredor por los caserios de Ica. El Sr. Cesar viene realizando esta actividad hace 7 años. El cuenta con metas que cumplir como el de tener un negocio mucho mas amplio en lugar propio. Con el dinero que solicita sera para surtir su mercaderia para la campaña navideña que se aproxima.
texts.en: Cesar is 43 years old.  He is single and has his own home which he inherited from his mother.  He lives alone in La Tinguiña district in a one-level adobe house.  He works selling clothes as an itinerant salesman in La Unión market and also on Saturdays and Sundays around the villages of Ica.  Cesar has been in this business for 7 years.  He has goals which he would like to fulfil such as expanding his business and having his own premises for his business.  He will use the money he is requesting to stock his business with more merchandise for the Christmas period which is approaching.

loans.use: To stock his business for the Christmas period

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah is a resident of Kisii Town in Western Kenya where he does mixed farming. He has 9 children with 7 still attending school. He has employed 8 farmhands. He produces bananas, tea and maize.

He has requested for a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He plans to use the income for school fees. He believes it will also supplement his family's diet. He is also focusing on buying three motorcycles to help in the transportation of bananas to the market and double as another business. He currently runs a retail shop as additional source of income.

Low prices for bananas in the market and insufficient funds are his greatest challenges. He adds Juhudi Kilimo has provided "the light to uplift living standards"

loans.use: Purchase and insurance of a dairy cow.

loans.name: Nouth

texts.en:
Mrs. Nouth N. is a 37-year-old farmer residing in a rural area of Kompong Tom Province. She feeds some pigs in a pigpen behind her house. Eventually, she will sell her pigs to a slaughterer in four-month cycles. Her husband works cutting firewood, and he has owns a rice hulling machine inside his home for providing rice milling services to his neighbors for extra income. 

This couple has two kids, still living with them till present. Usually Mrs. Nouth N. generates around US$3 of profit a day to meet the needs of her family. In order to earn more income, Mrs. Nouth N. will be using the loan to buy more pig feed and piglets to raise.

loans.use: To buy more pig feed and piglets to raise

loans.name: Luz Del Transito

texts.es: Luz del Transito se dedica a la venta de ropa. Es una mujer muy emprendedora y luchadora tiene 2 hijos que son menores de edad y están a su cargo. Sus inicio se dan necesitaba una fuente de ingreso para mantener a su familia. Luz tiene que levantarse todos los días temprano para arreglar las cosas que tendrá que ofrecer a sus diferentes clientes. Ella solicita este crédito para la compra de camisas, faldas, trajes y vestidos ya que tiene ciertos pedidos por esta época.
texts.en:
Luz del Transito sells clothes. She is an enterprising and determined woman who has two young children in her care. This business provides a needed source of income to support her family. Luz must wake up early every day in order to arrange the merchandise that she will offer to different customers.

She is requesting this loan to buy shirts, skirts, suits, and dresses since she has pending orders at the moment.

loans.use: Operating capital to acquire clothing

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.ar:
ابراهيم في عمر 47 سنة يعمل في تعهدات وورش البناء له في عمله 27 سنة يحب عمله ويبرع فيه فهو نشيط وطموح
متزوج وله اربع اولاد يحب عائلته ويسعى ائما الى تأمين العيش الكريم لهم وتعليهم في مستوى جيد يريد من خلال طلب قرض له من
المجموعة الى شراء مواد اولية للورش وتوسيع العمل له مميزات في عمله فهو دقيق صادق ونشيط يحب دائما ان
يزيد من مدخوله المادي وتحسين وضعه لاجتماعي
texts.en: Ibrahim is a 47-year-old husband and father of four who loves his family very much and wants to provide them with a decent education and standard of living. Ibrahim has 27 years of experience working in contracting and workshops. He is very distinguished in his work, which he invests with great vigor, passion, and thoroughness. Ibrahim is now seeking a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase raw materials for his shop and expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for workshop

loans.name: Sumitra

texts.en:
In the Kathmandu Valley, clothing is made to order. Tailor stalls line the streets where store owners sell material and work their sewing machines.  These skilled tailors make school uniforms for children as well as the the traditional women's kurta surwal and men's daura surwal. 

This is 40 year-old Sumitra B.. She is married and has one child, aged 1. In 2000, she established her tailoring business. Working seven days a week and seven hours a day, she supports her family.  

With a Kiva loan, BPW borrowers like Sumitra are able to purchase additional cloth material or sewing machines that will increase production and profitability. Sumitra has already received and successfully repaid a loan from Patan BPW. She is using her most recent loan to buy materials for her tailoring work.  

In the future, Sumitra plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.  

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner microfinance institution, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our BPW Partner Page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates. Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team

loans.use: To buys materials for her tailoring business

loans.name: John Irungu

texts.en:
John has been running his retail shop in Naivasha town for the last four years.  He is 30 years old, married to Ann Wanjiru, and they have one child.

John was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan.  He repaid his first loan of Kshs 20,000 well and in good time.  He plans to use this loan amount to buy rice, flour, sugar in bulk to later sell in small quantities.

In the future, John would like to grow his shop to a wholesale business.

loans.use: To buy rice, flour, sugar in bulk to sell in small quantities

loans.name: Anushavan

texts.en: Anushavan started this business in 1998.  He sells glass and makes tables for traders in the market. Now he wants to enlarge his business and to increase his sales, so he will buy some more equipment and raw materials for his business. Anushavan lives with seven people: himself, his wife, his retired parents, and his three school-aged children. Anushavan is also an engineer.

loans.use: equipment and materials for his business

loans.name: Zinabala Nasuuti Development Group-Mukono

texts.en:
36-year-old  M. Annet has now been working in her tailoring business in Nasuuti-Mukono for four years. Annet who is single with no children yet says she began this business out of her own enterprise. Before that she was in more of a wits' ends situation. She cites diligence as one variable which has kept her business growing by leaps and bounds. 

Weekly she says this business generates shillings 65,000 as profits and she says with this loan, she is going to purchase more cloth and materials for making clothing. Annet belongs to Zinabala Nasuuti Development Group-Mukono.

loans.use: to purchase more cloth and materials for making clothing.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith, 36, is a mother of 4 children between 2 and 12 years. She is a dairy farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya, where she has been farming for ten years. Her farm is currently producing milk and tea which are sold to the local market.

She has requested a loan of 40,000 Kes through Juhudi Kilimo to construct a zero grazing unit. The extra income from this loan will enable her improve her family's livelihood and pay school fees for her children. Her major challenge has been the fluctuating market prices of milk, which makes it hard for budgeting.

loans.use: to construct a zero grazing (stall-feeding) unit.

loans.name: Mr. Ly Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. Ly, who was born in 1949, is the village bank president, as selected by ten people who make up a village bank loan. Each portion of the loan will be used for different purposes to improve their families' standards of living. 

Mr. Ly is a vice village chief and a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land where he can grow rice. He sells part of the rice and uses the rest of the rice to support his family. In the rice field he has some problems because it is time for growing. So to improve this condition, Mr. Ly is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer to do farming this dry season. He is a widower and has three children, one of whom is a monk, while the other one is a seamstress in a garment factory. The third child is a cow breeder.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer to do farming.

loans.name: Mgeni

texts.en:
Mgeni is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. Her husband is a businessman who supports his family financially. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.
